awd_titl_txt: Cluster Algebras, Combinatorics, and Knot Theory
awd_abstract_narration:
When cluster algebras were introduced by Fomin and Zelevinsky in 2002, their original motivation came from representation theory, which is a branch of modern algebra. Studying the symmetries of a model is often more fruitful than studying the model directly, and representation theory has found many applications in physics and chemistry as well as in other mathematical fields. The cluster algebras provide a mathematical framework for fundamental patterns which occur throughout representation theory. Surprisingly, these patterns are also observed in various other branches of science which, a priori, are not related to representation theory. This project will provide new directions of research in an already highly active research area. The investigator will establish and develop relations between cluster  algebras and other areas of mathematics. These new connections allow explicit computational results as well as structural development. The project contains the instigation of new ideas as well as the investigation of longstanding open questions.

The project focuses on cluster algebras and  their relation to combinatorics, knot theory, number theory and  representation theory of finite-dimensional algebras. The investigator will pursue several investigations. He will apply his recent discovery of a relation between cluster algebras and continued fractions to study classical problems in number theory from a new point of view and to apply the machinery of continued fractions to develop new tools in cluster algebras. He will also establish and develop a new connection between cluster algebras and knot theory providing explicit combinatorial formulas for Jones polynomials and other knot invariants. Furthermore, he will continue his study of the representation theory of finite-dimensional non-commutative algebras that arise from cluster algebras.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project focuses on cluster algebras and their relation to combinatorics, knot theory and number theory.  Cluster algebras are commutative algebras with a special combinatorial structure and are related to various fields in mathematics and physics. A cluster algebra is generated by its cluster variables. These are polynomials in several variables that are constructed by a recursive method called mutation.

 

Intellectual Merit. 

The first main result [Rabideau-Schiffler 2020, Lee-Li-Rabideau-Schiffler] is the proof of three conjectures on the order of Markov numbers known as Aigner's conjectures. The Markov numbers are a classical topic in number theory that has important ramifications in approximation theory, hyperbolic geometry, and combinatorics of words. The Markov numbers are parametrized by pairs of relatively prime positive integers (x,y) with x greater than y. If we think of these pairs as being points in the plane, we can formulate the conjectures by saying that the Markov numbers increase along all straight lines of slope at least -1. The PI's result is considerably stronger than these conjectures, namely it shows that the Markov numbers increase along all straight lines of slope at least -8/7~-1.14 and decrease along all straight lines of slope at most -5/4=-1.25. An important step towards this result, the discovery of a connection between cluster algebras and continued fractions, was also achieved in this project [Canakci-Schiffler 2018, 2020]. 

The second main result [Lee-Schiffler 2019] establishes a relation between cluster algebras and knot theory by realizing the Jones polynomial of 2-bridge knots as a specialization of a cluster variable. The cluster variable is given in an ad hoc construction that uses the fact that the 2-bridge knots are parametrized by continued fractions and the aforementioned connection between cluster algebras and continued fractions. The relation between cluster algebras and knot theory was extended to arbitrary knots and links in subsequent work [Bazier-Matte-Schiffler 2022] which realizes the Alexander polynomial as a specialized cluster variable. In contrast to the previous result, this approach is conceptual. 

Another main development is the construction of a combinatorial model for the syzygy categories of dimer tree algebras. These algebras arise naturally in cluster algebras as well as in mathematical physics. A syzygy is a submodule of a projective module. In two papers [Schiffler-Serhiyenko 2021] prove that the category of syzygies over a dimer tree algebra is equivalent to a combinatorial category of 2-diagonals in a regular polygon. Each indecomposable syzygy corresponds to a diagonal. Moreover, the polygon comes with a checkerboard pattern that encodes the projective resolutions of the syzygies.

Another major result of the award is the introduction of frieze varieties [Lee, Li, Mills, Schiffler, Seceleanu 2020]. These are algebraic varieties that are defined via the combinatorics of cluster algebras. The dimension of the frieze variety provides a new characterization of the representation type of the underlying quiver of the cluster algebra. The question whether these varieties are invariant under mutation was studied in [Igusa-Schiffler 2021]. 

Further results were obtained on the relation between cluster algebras and representation theory  [Duan-Schiffler 2020, Schiffler-Serna 2020, Gao-Schiffler 2020], and on combinatorial aspects of cluster algebras [Chang-Schiffler 2019, Lee-Li-Schiffler 2020, Gunawan-Schiffler 2020].

 

Broader Impacts.

The PI is one of the main organizers of the Programme on Cluster Algebras and Representation Theory at the Isaac Newton Institute, Cambridge, UK from September to December 2021. Many of the participants were early career researchers. Each participant gave a presentation in the seminar or in one of the conferences. The program included two 5-day conferences and one 5-day school as well as a biweekly seminar and a weekly open problem session. The school was aimed at PhD-students and postdocs and consisted in 5 mini courses on current research topics in the area of cluster algebras and representation theory. In addition, the program hosted two public lectures, one by Rothschild Fellow Bernhard Keller and the other by Kirk Fellow Gordana Todorov. Both Keller and Todorov also presented a three hour minicourse on current research topics.  

The PI is one of the organizers of the Online Cluster Algebra Seminar, a weekly online seminar that ran during the academic year 2020/21. This seminar provided a meeting place for researchers from Europe and the Americas to present and discuss current research on cluster algebras in times of the pandemic. 

In addition, the PI served as a member of the scientific committee for the International Conference on Representations of Algebras in 2020, a member of the editorial board of the Journal and the Bulletin of the London Mathematical Society and as a guest editor for a special issue on cluster algebras of the journal SIGMA. 

The PI supervised the postdocs Emily Gunawan and Veronique Bazier-Matte, the PhD students Hanpeng Gao, P.J. Apruzzese, Damian Wesenberg and Ryan Schroeder as well as the Masters student David Whiting during the time of the award.
